ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Hao Deng  Hao Deng
Instructor: Hao Deng  Hao Deng
Instructor: Hao Deng  Hao

Instructor: Hao Deng  I interacted with both TAs and they were excellent. They were always available to provide explanations and answer students questions. They would even schedule additional office hours when needed.
Instructor: Hao Deng  Hao Deng
Instructor: Jesse Brodie Burkhardt  Jesse Burkhardt
Instructor: Jesse Brodie Burkhardt  Jesse Burkhardt
Instructor: Jesse Brodie Burkhardt  Jesse.

Instructor: Jesse Brodie Burkhardt  Jesse. But I worked with both of them on problem sets. Jesse's office hours were better for me, and I found it easier to learn from him so I kept going to his hours.
Instructor: Jesse Brodie Burkhardt  Jesse Burkhardt
Instructor: Jesse Brodie Burkhardt  He was a strong TA, who knew the concepts and provided us insights for homework that weren't always clear from the initial instructions.
Instructor: Jesse Brodie Burkhardt  Jesse
Instructor: Jesse Brodie Burkhardt  Jesse Burkhardt
Instructor: Jesse Brodie Burkhardt  Jesse Burkhardt
Instructor: Jesse Brodie Burkhardt  Jesse Burkhardt
Instructor: Jesse Brodie Burkhardt  Jesse
Instructor: Jesse Brodie Burkhardt  Jesse was a valuable resource over the course of the semester, particularly in helping to parse through the homework questions.
Instructor: Jesse Brodie Burkhardt  Didn't have many interactions.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Hao Deng  Hao is very nice and can explain the questions clearly!

Instructor: Hao Deng  Some concepts in the homework assignments were relatively difficult and it seemed that there was little communication between the professor and the assistants ahead of time. They could talk briefly about the problem sets in the future.
Instructor: Hao Deng  Honestly, no weaknesses, keep up the good work

Instructor: Hao Deng  Hao made himself very available, and was willing to stay as long as necessary for each student to understand what the assignments were asking and how the concepts worked. Sometimes it took several students to ask different versions of the same question before Hao finally understood what we were asking, which at times, was a source of frustration. He never gave up on our questions, however, and if he didn't know an answer, he made sure to send it out later.
Instructor: Jesse Brodie Burkhardt  Jesse was fantastic all around. He was more accessible than Hao, and very willing to help.
Instructor: Jesse Brodie Burkhardt  He was always available to guard me in understanding some of the concepts discussed in class.

Instructor: Jesse Brodie Burkhardt  Overall, my experience with the TAs was a positive one. However, sometimes the problem sets were worded confusingly or the equations were incorrect. The TAs did not know how to handle these issues and often there was no outreach to the entire class. If a student was unable to attend the option TA sessions, s/he would not have had all the information necessary to complete the problem set.
Instructor: Jesse Brodie Burkhardt  Very friendly, approachable, knowledgable, responsive, accessible. No complaints.

Instructor: Jesse Brodie Burkhardt  Jesse was extremely helpful. He was able to clearly and comprehensively explain complex topics and questions that significantly added to my understanding of subjects in the class. He is kind and thoughtful and we all appreciated his effort. My only suggestion would be that in light of the significant gap between what was covered in class and the problem set material, a bit more emphasis on a short, structured lesson in tutorial time might have been helpful.
Instructor: Jesse Brodie Burkhardt  Responsive, prepared useful review sessions, timely
Instructor: Jesse Brodie Burkhardt  Very clear in leading TA sessions and helping to explain HW assignments. Also very accessible.

Instructor: Jesse Brodie Burkhardt  Friendly and tried to be of help, but did not really know as much about the subject matter as he really should (asking really obvious or confusing questions in class and during our group project review sessions).
Instructor: Jesse Brodie Burkhardt  More comments/feedback on hw assignments would be helpful.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Ken is an excellent professor.
The overall class was good. The material was excellent and well organized. However, the course felt like an undergraduate class because both the PSets, and exams were way too easy.
Excellent course, must-take class. This is the type of course that gives you some real in-demand skills for the job market or academia. Instructor and TAs are available and ready to answer questions.
As with many classes, the degree of learning is largely dependent on the student's investment in the reading.
Great course and excellent professor. But he doesn't moderate class with enough force. Too many silly student comments were given air time.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The contents that this class include are interesting and useful, and can give the students a sense of the basic energy economics, as well as the current policy origins.

This is a course about real world problems in the energy space. Issues of economic theory are explored not for their own sake, but as ways to explain what is actually happening. It is really well taught - Ken Gillingham is an excellent teacher. There is a lot of reading other work for the course, but it is well worth it - I got an enormous amount out of the course.
Class discussion, lecture material and home works.
The group project in the realm of energy policy sector.
The readings were great. The final project was an excellent opportunity to take a deep dive on a particular subject.
The readings were extremely dense, but good. There was lots of personal learning involved, which was facilitated by lectures.
Lectures - relevant and interesting Group project
A terrific learning experience. We covered A LOT of material in this class and it was well presented and well-designed. The overall work was very heavy but in the end, I learned a lot.
Problem sets re-enforced course lecture materials and readings. Course was taught at a good pace and covered a breadth of relevant topics.
Otganized
All

Learning from Ken, who is a very good teacher, and learning the latest research and issues in energy economics and policy was very helpful. The group projects were very interesting to do and hear from as well.
The range of topics covered in the course -- almost all of current relevance.
Professor's insight, readings, presentations.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I suggest the professor to have a better control of the pace of the class, rather than turning the class to a totally discussion time which may not be that valuable.

The instructor answers every student question, and there were lots of them - in general, this was very positive. Occasionally, however, a student would ask too many questions that were too far off topic, and those classes would have flowed better if the instructor had asked the student to ask the questions outside of class.
Professor Gillingham needs to make sure that the course progresses at an appropriate pace. If this means that he cannot answer each and every students questions, then so be it.
The problem sets could have been worded better and several contained errors.

Consider including both government failures as well as market failures as topics in the class. Future policy makers need to understand the balance needed between policy as a tool for addressing market failures, as well as a tool that can be used by government that could intentionally/inadvertently stifle growth. The economics literature we reviewed covered market failures well, but when policy is being developed, there are other considerations to account for beyond economics.

You should just call the "midterm" a final... it was totally a final. That quantitative work in the problem sets were not linked or supported in lecture. You basically had to go to the TF session, which I didn't like. The readings were redundant and there were too many readings assigned. I would have done more readings, but it was hard to tell what was important and what wasn't. Plus the lectures crystalized the important parts of the readings. I liked that all the readings were very current though.
Class lectures were sometimes too focused on re-iterating the readings, instead of moving beyond them.
A basic textbook of economic concepts to refer to would be nice. That seemed lacking at times.

Ken could do a better job of managing student questions to keep the class on target. Questions and comments often went off target and I feel like we could've spent more time on other, more useful things. Ken intentionally creates an environment where questions and comments are welcome, however I think he takes this openness too far. Also, having a few guest lecturers on politics and the political feasibility/tactics towards certain policy objectives would have been great. Ken is an incredible economist, but not well-versed on politics. Perhaps this class could be paired with a energy politics class. Also, a lot to cover- we went into very much detail on some things and too little on others. Again, maybe better as a two-part course. I'd also prefer less academic articles, more newspaper/magazine articles. In sum, a little too heavy on the economics side.
Level of difficulty needs to be pulled up. It didn't feel like a masters class.
I can't see so far.
At times Ken indulged too much in answering questions (some more frivolous or less germane than others), thereby slowing the pace of the class and being unable to cover other interesting material.

It sometimes felt as though there was a bit of a disconnect between the hw assignments and the material covered in class -- particularly in terms of the more quantitative questions. There was an expected base of knowledge that I'm not sure everyone possessed.
Ability of the Prof to control class discussions and proceed efficiently through material.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The course lectures and discussions/sessions were very effective.
That quantitative work in the problem sets were not linked or supported in lecture. You basically had to go to the TF session, which I didn't like.
Yes, except the gap between the high-level concepts covered in class and the details in the problem sets could have been narrower
yes

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: The class give me some basic sense of the energy economics, and the policies mainly focusing on U.S.. This enable me to have a general knowledge of the policy background for energy issues.
My program is focused on energy issues, so this course was central to my program.
I am interested in energy issues so this course fits my interest.
Core part of the curriculum for energy folks.
I would like to work in the energy sector and figured this course would help improve my analytical tools.
Very useful.
Essential course. Every student with a focus in energy should take this course.
Interested in energy policy, so this course is crucial
This course fulfilled one requirement for my industrial ecology and green design specialization.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: It is central to my interest in energy issues
I took the course because of my interest in energy policy in the US.
Related to my future work. General interest in energy policy.
I wanted an Econ class, but didn't want to take the basic one (because I took it in undergrad). I also wanted to learn more about energy.
Energy specialization
To be able to implement rigorous policy analysis based on the economics.
I took this course to satisfy my specialization requirement, to learn more about energy economics and policy, and to learn from Ken.
I am exploring water-energy issues while at FES.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Mostly, but would welcome more clear explanation of different policy cases.
Yes - or I should say, exceeded my expectations
Yes
Yes.
yes
Yes.
Yes - great class
Completely.
YES!
Yes

Yes--especially since I didn't have extensive energy or economics background, all the stuff I learned was new and valuable, and I have been seeing the concepts I learned pop up in current events frequently.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I worked with a group of smart people, and I enjoyed the process. One thing to mention is to allocate the work in a team, to make sure everyone can learn something through the group project.

Advantages: learning from peers Disadvantages: Since the course prerequisites are not strictly enforced, some students were liabilities to the various teams. This put an unfair onus on others to carry the load for the team.
I learned a lot from the group work.
It was good. Always hard with schedules.
I really appreciated the opportunity to delve into energy modeling. It would be good to have some group-evaluation process, as we had very unequal participation from group members.
It is supposed to help spread the load of a larger project, but there needs to be better guidance in the beginning as to how each project should be tailored.
Fantastic experience to learn from my peers and to develop creative solutions to concepts we learned in class. Well facilitated by Prof. Gillingham.
The usual... good group members and bad group members. I think the course design of the group project was fine.
Pros: learning from people with a diversity of backgrounds and work styles Cons: Having to do more than my share of the project work
Group project was less beneficial than individual research that I could have done.
Group project was excellent, and an opportunity to work in team.

Doing the group project was fun and definitely helped to make the class more 'hands-on'. Ken and the TAs gave fabulous support all throughout the project, which made it even more of a learning experience. Hearing from all the other groups was very fascinating and illuminating as well.
Adv: having the opportunity to explore a topic of interest in depth Dis: borderline dysfunctional group dynamics at times.

Advantages included division of labor and valuable discussion on economic concepts. A disadvantage of group work was variance in the quantitative ability of group members. A more structured, in-class approach to economic analysis would have been helpful (rather than just problem sets). Because the project was centered around a quantitative analysis, a lack of ability or experience in economic/quantitative analysis limited the contribution of certain group members.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Reading is super important!

This course is crucial for anyone who wants to work in the energy space. There is a lot of quantitative work in the class, in the problem sets. But the TAs did an excellent job of getting everyone in the class, even those who do not have a quantitative orientation, through the assignments, so this should not deter anyone from taking the class. And the overall course material is just so fascinating.
Great course being taught by an excellent professor.
Get started on your group work early.
If you are into energy OR policy, its a great course.

VERY HEAVY WORKLOAD but well worth it- just be prepared when you combine this with other work-intensive courses. In all, I probably spent an average of 20+ hours per week on this course between readings, problem sets, exam, final presentation, and final paper.
Work in a small group. But choose a project you really like
I highly recommend. Be ready to put in the hours.

I don't know when the next time this class will be offered (probably in 2 years after Ken gets back from his White House service?) but when it is offered, definitely take it if you have any interest in energy issues (including transportation)!
work early and often on the group paper

Take it! It's great. Professor is very smart and engaging. Just ensure that the students stay focused and participate. Also, the professor should prohibit laptops in class - too many students on the internet.
